articles.description: U.S. President Donald Trump’s special envoy to Ukraine, retired Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg, arrived in Kyiv on Monday. Discussions will focus on defense, security, and U.S.-Ukraine cooperation. Trump has expressed frustration with Russian President Vladimir Putin over continued attacks on Ukraine, calling Putin’s actions “crazy.” The U.S. is sending Patriot missiles to help Ukraine counter Russia’s intensified aerial strikes. June saw record civilian casualties, with Russia launching significantly more attacks than last year. Meanwhile, NATO’s Secretary-General is in Washington for talks, and Sen. Lindsey Graham claims the conflict is at a turning point, with increased U.S. support for Ukraine expected soon.
articles.title: Trump envoy Kellogg in Kyiv as US pledges Patriot missiles to Ukraine

articles.description: U.S. President Donald Trump repeatedly said during his campaign he would be able to end the war between Russia and Ukraine “in 24 hours” upon taking office. But since his Jan. 20 inauguration, the road to a peace deal has been fraught with changing dynamics between the U.S. leader, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Trump’s rhetoric toward both Zelenskyy and Putin has evolved during the first months of his second term in the White House. The Republican leader has become increasingly exasperated with Putin in recent days, while he appears to have softened toward Zelenskyy after a February blowout in the Oval Office.
articles.title: In his words: Trump's rhetoric about Zelenskyy and Putin has evolved

articles.description: A wildfire along the Grand Canyon's North Rim grew rapidly over the weekend and destroyed a historic lodge and visitors center. Firefighters are working to slow down the fire that began on July 4 after a lightning trike. The fire is in a less popular area of the Grand Canyon that draws only about 10% of the park's millions of visitors. Evacuations were ordered over concerns that include chlorine gas exposure after a treatment plant burned. Arizona Gov. Katie Hobbs has called for a federal investigation into the fire's management. Another wildfire in Colorado has closed Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park, prompting evacuations and a disaster declaration by the state’s governor.
articles.title: Grand Canyon fire along North Rim destroy historic lodge

articles.description: The man accused of killing two women at a Kentucky church and wounding a state trooper in separate shootings had been expected in court for a domestic violence hearing the next day. Guy House was fatally shot by police on Sunday at Richmond Road Baptist Church. The Lexington Herald-Leader reported that House went to the church looking for the mother of his children, but his domestic violence hearing on Monday did not involve her. Authorities say he also wounded two men in the rampage, which began when House shot the trooper during a traffic stop near Lexington’s airport. The shootings remain under investigation.
articles.title: Kentucky church shooting suspect had an upcoming domestic violence hearing

articles.description: Authorities are reporting multiple deaths in a fire at an assisted living facility in Fall River, Massachusetts, where people were hanging out of windows screaming for help. The fire broke out Sunday night at the Gabriel House facility, which houses about 70 residents. Firefighters arrived to find heavy smoke, flames, and occupants trapped inside. Many residents were rescued, but several were pronounced dead at the scene. Others were taken to hospitals with varying injuries. Five firefighters sustained non-life-threatening injuries. Officials say the cause of the fire is under investigation. The local fire chief called the incident a devastating tragedy for the community and affected families.
articles.title: Multiple deaths in fire at Massachusetts assisted living facility

articles.description: Senate Republicans are putting the popularity of Department of Government Efficiency spending cuts to the test this week. The GOP lawmakers are looking to pass President Donald Trump’s request to claw back $9.4 billion in spending on public media and foreign aid. Senate Democrats are looking to kill the measure. The House has already approved the rescissions package on a mostly party line 214-212 vote. The Senate has little time to spare to beat the 45-day deadline for the Republican president’s signature. If Congress fails to act by Friday, then the spending stands.
articles.title: Senate vote will test the popularity of DOGE spending cuts

articles.description: Programs that provide summer and after-school programming to more than 1 million students are at risk because of a Trump administration freeze on education grants. Congress set aside money for the programs at Boys & Girls Clubs, the YMCA and public schools to provide academic support, enrichment and child care. But President Donald Trump's administration says it wants to make sure recipients’ programs align with the Republican president’s priorities. The Boys & Girls Club of America says many clubs have found ways to keep their summer programs open but there isn’t the same hope for the after-school programming this fall. The Boys & Girls Club of East Providence, Rhode Island, says the state helped with funding.
articles.title: Trump funding freeze threatens Boys & Girls Club child care programs

articles.description: Clashes between Druze militias and Sunni Bedouin clans in Syria's Sweida province have killed more than 30 people and injured nearly 100. The interior ministry said Monday that military forces will deploy to restore order. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported 37 deaths and said the violence began after kidnappings and robberies escalated tensions between Druze and Sunni Bedouin groups. The ministry called the situation a dangerous escalation fueled by the absence of effective governance. Sweida is home to Syria’s Druze minority and has seen unrest since the fall of former leader Bashar Assad, with Druze factions divided over integrating with the new government.
articles.title: More than 30 killed in Syria clashes

articles.description: Each year, choking claims the lives of more than 4,100 Americans who are 65 or older. It’s the most vulnerable age group, accounting for about three-quarters of U.S. choking deaths. A number of companies are marketing antichoking devices to the elderly. They vary in design, but generally the devices look like a face mask attached to a tube or bellows, with a handle at the end. Medical professionals have been debating whether to endorse the products, saying more research is needed. Experts — and even antichoking device manufacturers — say that back blows and abdominal thrusts should always be tried first.
articles.title: A device or the Heimlich maneuver: What to do when someone is choking

articles.description: Fast fashion relies heavily on synthetic fibers that are made from oil and gas, fossil fuels that cause climate change. Once discarded, many of those materials end up in landfills. Some designers are working to cut those products out completely and instead use biomaterials. They are experimenting with tapioca, gelatin, agar agar, mushrooms, and other kitchen-shelf ingredients. Big names like Stella McCartney and Hermes have experimented with biomaterials like mushroom leather, while other early adopters are making fabrics out of corn and soy. Some experts are skeptical these textiles can be scaled up, but designers experimenting with biomaterials believe their experimentation could help push the industry away from the heavy pollution and waste that it currently produces.
articles.title: Fashion designers experiment with natural supplies called biomaterials
